Posts.Content: I am new to the forum and recently replied to a post on another thread by mapleleaf. I have been diagnosed with Gleason 6 prostate cancer. I have gathered pros and cons on treatments / no treatment, a lot of which were distilled from this forum and would be interested in thoughts on the results of my biopsy and tests before indicating where my mind is at. Please see my signature below. I am meeting with my urologist in a week and a half to go over the biopsy results. Up till this year my health has been uneventful. I am retired, a life-long non-smoker, exercise regularly, eat properly and am slim. I have a lot of relatives, most of whom live into their late 80's to mid-90's. I am counting on doing the same! My Dad died at almost 93 and had Alzheimers. I am told he also had prostate cancer but he did not die of that. No other family prostate cancer that I know of. Thank you for your thoughts!
Posts.Signature: Regular Check-up April, 2018 Age 66 at DX Negative DRE PSA 6.2 first test - May 2018 6.6 2nd test, two weeks later - May 2018 free PSA 0.09 first test, 0.26 2nd test ! 2017 PSA was 2.8 PSA 2.5 Sept 18 2018, free PSA 0.2 PSA 1.9 April 2 2019 (corrected from 0.95) Free PSA 0.2 All PSAs corrected, i.e. doubled for finasteride use PSA velocity and free PSA concerns told symptomatic for BPH for a few years slow flow, hesitant flow mp-MRI with contrast, no coil 05/30/18 Pirads-4 ill defined area of T-2 hypointensity 8 mm right anterolateral peripheral zone mid gland Biopsy results of 06/25/18: targeted and random, 20 biopsies All negative except for one: Gleason 3+3=6, right apex, 10% of tissue, moderately differentiated No extra-organ extensions, invasions, etc. Volume 39 mL PSAD 0.16 Biopsy results of 10/18/18: targeted and random, 17 biopsies All negative for malignancy.
Posts.Title: Newbie from Ottawa

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone for the informative replies! They are greatly appreciated and I certainly will add the suggestions to my list of questions for the urologist! I had been thinking that most people (including my urologist) would indicate Active Surveillance. Indeed though that Pirads-4 issue needs to be understood or reclassified. So that as well as all the other suggestions! You can be sure I am noting them and studying them closely. I agree with the comments that a Gleason 7 may have been missed. Whether the biopsy is a good enough indication is my biggest concern about AS and waiting another year for another biopsy but I would understand some of the other suggested tests now might lessen those concerns or cause me to revisit having treatments. I note the doctor's report of the actual biopsy procedure said about the MRI Pirads-4 lesion: “Sonographic nodule corresponding to MRI target lesion: No. Therefore the area of concern on MRI was targeted with multiple extra samples.” She did note the bottles containing targeted biopsies and one was labeled as #9 (right apex). That is the bottle that had the Gleason 6. So, it would seem at least that the targeted area resulted in one positive.
